description.text: We landed in Venice in the middle of the day after a very long day of flights and connections. The temperature was perfect: warm with a nice breeze. We hopped on the Linia Blu ferry and got a great little tour of the city. We stopped at a bunch of different terminals and were able to get the lay of the land. We reached our stop and made our wade through the quiet streets of Lido to our hotel, stopping to smell the flowers on the way.

The room was great. The windows went to the ceiling and when we opened them we heard bird songs that would calm any weary traveler. We cleaned ourselves up and had a much needed nap before heading to the main street for dinner at the Lido Cafe.
G: Ravioli, Aperol Spritz - 8/10
"Amazing ravioli! The garnish for the spritz nearly took out my eye."
M: Pizza, Aperol Spritz: 7.5/10
"Good pizza. Too many mosquitos.
We walked back and saw some neat buildings and went right to bed.
Today, we got up at 7 to seize the day and had the best continental breakfast of our lives.  M tried out the cappuccino machine which, to our delight, was fantastic
G: Apricot jam pie, chocolate rice krispies, fresh meats and cheeses. 10/10
M: Parfait, cornetto, fresh meats and cheeses, cream puff, cappuccino. 10/10

After breakfast we returned to the room to create a plan of attack and iron our well-packed clothes to better fit in with the fashionable venetians. We left the room around 9AM and got ourselves set up with a new phone plan. We went to a cafe and had another cappuccino to compare it against the hotel's digital barista; it was better.

We left the coffee shop and headed to the vaporetto.  We secured ourselves 2 48hr passes and headed for the main city. We had tickets for the Peggy Gugenheim Modern Art Museum at 11:30 so had some time to kill.  We got off at the Gardinia station a few stops before our final stop. The gardens were beautiful.
We hopped back on the ferry to get to the museum. We still had a bit of time to kill so just before entering we got some gelato.
G: Pistachio 7.5/10
Extreme velvet with fresh cone
M: Caffe 7.5/10
Good ice cream.  A bit over-hyped

We rolled into the museum and were greeted with a garden full of complex and ornate statues. It was humbling to see famous artists work in person. It was also inspiring to see the early works of some of them. The featured artist(Jean Cocteau) exhibit was...interesting.

After the Gugenheim we wandered to a quiet square and were greeted by some pigeons and an accordion player. It was a nice, calm moment where we just sat, listened to the music, and watched the birds. It was one of the nicest moments of our trip to have the little square all to ourselves and relax with "Can't help falling in love" quietly playing in the background.
When the sun started getting too hot we moved on to a cafe for lunch.
G: Spinach cannelloni with cheese sauce. 8/10
M: Focaccia prosciutto sandwich, Fanta. 7/10
Needed some veg. Italian Fanta was great.
Next we wandered into a local shop that sold purses and bags. Georgia has been looking for a good bag for a while. She splurged and went for italian leather that will hopefully last a lifetime.

After that we went on a world famous gondola ride and see the canals from the water. Our guide was a pro that has been a gondolier for 20 years. He took us through the Grand Canal and then into some side "streets" and showed us a gondola factory with dozens of gondolas piled up.

It was great being on the water but we decided to hide from the sun in the Gallerie del Accademia. There, we saw massive medieval works of art depicting battles and biblical scenes. There was a more modern section at the end that had some newer(from the 1800s) paintings and some marble statues. We weren't expecting to be as amazed as we were going in but were very happy we went.

After the gondola and the museum we returned to Lido and our hotel and planned some events for the next day.  There was a glass blowing class in the morning and a pasta making class in the evening and we signed up for both.
We went for dinner at Parco Delle Rose on main street.
G: Bruschetta, spaghetti bolognese, tiramisu, local wine 7/10
Tiramisu was a bit too wet but the wine was great!
M: Bruschetta, farfalle with garlic butter and sage, tiramisu, local wine 7.5/10

After dinner we walked to Lido Beach. It had a great view looking out over the Mediterranean. After the sun went down we walked back to the hotel and tried to sleep so that we could get up early for our glass blowing class.

A mosquito woke me up at 1:30 AM. This woke up Georgia, and neither of us could get back to sleep. The time change and the tiramisu for dinner probably didn't help. We used the opportunity to go back to Lido to catch the sunrise at 5:30.

The first cafe opened at 6. We got a cafe con latte and a cornetto to keep ourselves awake for the glass blowing class. Unfortunately, we got an email moments later telling us the class was canceled due to mechanical issues. We weren't too bothered as it gave us a bit of time to get some rest after breakfast.

I was able to get another couple hours of sleep but the coffee kept Georgia up. Even though we weren't able to do any glass blowing ourselves we decided we wanted to check out the island famous for it: Murano. We checked out the Murano Glass Museum and checked out some shops. We bought some glasses and Georgia got a new pair of earings at one of them. We had lunch on Murano.
G: Spaghetti pesto, lemoncello, pear juice 8/10
"The pear and apricot juices were both so sweet and so fresh!"
M: Spaghetti carbonara, lemoncello, apricot juice 8.5/10

Georgia was dressed for glass blowing class, not walking through the streets of Venice and was melting away so we went dress shopping. She found 2 new dresses that she loves and was much more comfortable in the heat.
At 6PM our pasta making class started. It was so much fun! We made tiramisu, tagliatelle, and ravioli. There was bottomless wine as well that really improved the final product.
After the class we went straight back to our hotel and fell asleep immediately.
Fresh pasta recipe (per person):
1 egg
100g 00 Flour
1. In a large mixing bowl, add the flower and create a well in the center.

2. Add the egg(s) to the well. Whisk the eggs with a fork until they are fully mixed. Once all the yolk and white are combined, slowly start pulling in flour from below the egg(s) and from the sides. Continue mixing until the egg is fully combined with the flour.
3. Knead the dough until it is smooth and it bounces back when you push your finger into it.

4a. With a pasta machine: Roll out the dough on the widest setting, coating with flour between rolls. Repeat this step twice on each setting before reducing the size. When your pasta is thin enough to see through it it's time to cut.

4b. With a rolling pin: Roll out the dough slowly. Try to keep rolling in the same direction to make sure you get long strips of dough. Keep doing this until the dough is thin enough to see through it.
5. Using either a knife or a pasta machine, carefully cut the flattened dough to desired thickness. Adding more flour to the noodles now will help prevent them from sticking together.
6. Add the noodles to a pot of boiling, salted water and cook for 3 mins.
7. Add your favourite sauce and enjoy!
We had a lovely breakfast and coffee at our hotel and enjoyed it outside in the garden to fully appreciate the space before we checked out and said goodbye to Lido.

We hopped on a ferry and went to our new hotel, Hotel Murcurio, for the last night to be closer to the opera that we would be seeing that night. The room wasn't ready but we were able to stash our bags there and go for lunch. While looking for a lunch place we stumbled across St Mark's Square, one of the biggest tourist attractions in the city. There were hundreds of people all checking out the space. Just around the corner from the square we found a little restaurant on a canal.
G: Mystery noodle & pesto, orange juice with Campari, cannoli and chocolate mousse, Aperol Spritz 8/10
M: Tortellini with garlic sauce, Campari Spritz, Bellini 8.5/10

After lunch we went back to the hotel to see our room. We climbed to the tippy top of the building and discovered our honeymoon suite dressed in rose petals and with a bottle of prosecco on the side table. We settled in to the room and then ventured back out into the narrow, twisting streets of central Venice for dinner.
G: Beetroot gnocchi with pistachio sauce and ricotta, white wine 9/10
M: Char-grilled pork chop, dill potatoes, asparagus, apple sauce, mystery crunchy veg thing, red wine 9.5/10

We finished dinner and went to the theatre across the street 20 minutes early only to find out that the show was at another place! It was a 12 minute walk away and we made it just in time despite our fancy shoes and google maps not working in Venice. We were'nt able to get an english program so we had to go by vibes for most of it. Even with the language barrier it was a great show.
We had our last breakfast in Venice.
G: Eggs, cheese, toast, bacon, hot chocolate 9/10
"The hot chocolate was so thick it could be a mousse if it was chilled."
M: Omelette, mocha, cornetto 8/10

After breakfast we went back to the hotel to check out and then made our way to the train station. We got there shortly before our departure. Unfortunately, there were no seats to be found at the station so we were stuck with our heavy bags.

We took our train to Milan and then a connection to Lugano where we crossed the border into Switzerland. As we crossed the border we lost cell service. When we arrived in Lugano we had to reorient ourselves and, while doing so, missed 3 busses. Finally, late and tired, we got on the 211 and took it all the way to the top of a mountain in Cademario where we were staying at the Kurhaus Spa.

The spa was beautiful and we got the couples package with all the bells and whistles including a 4 course meal, a room upgrade with an amazing view, a bottle of prosecco and rose petals in the room, and a couples massage. There was a large indoor/outdoor pool with different sections where you could turn on different types of jets. Past the pool were the saunas. 3 different types all with varying levels of heat and humidity, and a frigidarium for cold plunges between sauna sessions.
We spent 2 blissful days here recuperating from walking around Venice before moving on to our next adventure.

This morning we left the spa and headed back down the mountain to the train station. The train from Lugano to Bern took about 4 hours and brought us through some of the most mountainous parts of the country. The views were spectacular.

We arrived in Bern at around 2PM and headed to our hotel to check in. After getting rid of our bags we took a bus to the Rosengarten which is a public access park that overlooks the city. The views were, once again, spectacular.

Walking down the hill from the garden brought us to the famous Bern Bear Pit. There were no bears in sight. We grabbed a couple drinks at a brewery next door and took in the city and river that flows through it.
G: Pretzel and lager 7/10
M: Different pretzel and marzen 7/10

After some beer and pretzels we walked home, taking the scenic route along the river. Along the way we stumbled across a statue of Albert Einstein, we managed to see some bears, and we found the Zytglogge clock tower in the historic old town, just steps away from our hotel.

We woke up at 5AM to make sure we got to the train on time. We caught the 7AM connection and had breakfast on the train in the restaurant car on our way to Interlaken. We then got on another train that took us up the hill to Grindelwald where we could take the gondola up to the top of Jungfrau Mountain. The gondola took us to a lookout station where we could take yet another train that tunneled through the mountain the rest of the way to the peak.

We made it to the peak at about 10AM. We were immediately feeling the altitude. Georgia was a bit giddy. We had a snack, got our bearings and then started the tour. First stop was the Sphinx research center at the top, then we went down into the discovery cave that told the history of the area. Next was the ice palace where we walked through tunnels of ice and saw a bunch of ice sculptures. Finally we went out onto the glacier plateau. After the tour we went back inside for lunch and had some cheese fondue. There were a lot of places to get gifts included numerous watch shops and a fully stocked Lindt chocolate store.

We headed back down to Interlaken at 1. Once there we walked along the river and had a tea before going on to our next adventure: chocolate making! The class was great! We got to try a big variety of chocolate and made 3 different bars each.
We finished off our day trip to Interlaken with pizza and minestrone soup at a small restaurant and went back to Bern for bed.

After a very full day of adventuring yesterday we took our time getting up and then perused the shops in Bern. There were tons of fun bakeries and chocolatiers, we saw the Swiss parliament building, and we picked up some keepsakes for home.
On our way to the train we grabbed a sausage from a cart on the sidewalk. It was a foot long, in a baguette, and with mustard, ketchup, and a curry sauce. It was delicious. 10/10
After that we got on the train to Montreux. Georgia had a much needed nap. The landscape smoothed out a lot heading into the french part of the country.

At our new hotel in Montreux we were very warmly welcomed by our hotelier who told us much about himself, including how he loves his dog so much and couldn't believe that we were away from ours. He told us about Chillion Castle just south of town and how to get there. We didn't have anything planned for the day so thought we'd check it out.

Chillion Castle was a real castle. It had a dungeon, a keep, turrets, and all the other castley bits that one might imagine. We had free reign to go anywhere we wanted and see everything. It was cool. We ended the tour with Georgia dipping her toes in Lac Leman.
Next we went on a hangry wild goose chase with google maps sending us to closed restaurants. We ended up at a very fancy place called La Brasserie.
G: Steak and veg 8/10
M: Burger and wine 7/10

We excitedly awoke for our chocolate train tour this morning. We had first class tickets in a fancy car full of wood-accents that made you feel like you were on your way to Hogwarts. The train stopped in Gruyere where we took a bus to the cheese factory and learned how they make gruyere cheese.

After the cheese factory we had a lunch break at the medieval gruyere castle. As we had just been at a castle the day before we opted to check out the quintessential medieval village instead. To our surprise, we stumbled upon the H.R. Geiger museum which seemed rather out of place given the setting. We had to go in. It was interesting but disturbing. We left unsettled by all the nightmare fuel. Across the street was a bar themed after Geiger's work. Once again, we had to go in. It had spinal columns making up the core structure, and chairs and tables made to look like skeletons. We had grilled (gruyere) cheese sandwiches and finished it up with Xenomorph shots(which were surprisingly refreshing).

For the last leg of our tour we got back on the bus and went to the Cailler chocolate factory. We learned about the history of Cailler chocolate and got to see how they make them. There was a tasting section with about 10 different chocolates, but the line was moving quick so we didn't have much time to savour the flavour in between each one. We shoveled the treats into our mouths and moved on feeling ill from all the chocolate.
The bus brought us back to Montreux and we stopped at an irish pub before heading to our hotel for the night.

We woke up on our last full day in Europe. We had breakfast at the hotel before heading to Geneva. We got in to the city, walked around a little bit and then grabbed a coffee, but it started raining. We checked into our hotel and had a rest as we were both tired.
In the evening we set out to have one last adventure: a michelin restaurant. Le Chat Botte is right on the water overlooking Geneva's giant fountain. We had the 5 course vegetarian tasting menu
Apertif
3 small bites. One that was a mochi consistency herbal explosion. The next was a smokey cheese bread thing. The last was a thin layer of parsley gel over a cheesy cracker.
First Course
Pea coconut gazpacho with pickled strawberries and a cracker ring.
Second Course
This course was dedicated to the tomato. Foamed tomato filled with jammed tomato on top of a cracker with creamy herbal reduction and a tomato ravioli with cheese and tomato filling.
Third Course
Deep fried zucchini flower and cheese, grilled zucchini, zucchini noodles,  onion gravy and drops of lemon mustard.
Fourth Course
Seared fennel root with a refreshing gelled outer layer covered in browned onion butter
Fifth Course

Corn in many ways. Baby corn, popcorn, and sweet corn kernels enjoyed with a pepper paste. Corn bread shaped like popcorn on a bed of popcorn kernels. And finally, a cream corn mousse that tickled the tongue.
Pallet Cleanser
Strawberry sorbet with a meringue.
Dessert
G: Poached Rhubarb and honeycomb cracker on a soft nougat.
M: Cracker on ice cream on meringue drizzled with a kiwi compote.
Bonus Chocolate
4 little bites presented on a bed of cocoa nibs. A milk chocolate, a raspberry marshmallow, a dark chocolate, and a raspberry flavoured soft candy.
